September is National Suicide Prevention Month. Suicidal thoughts can affect people of all ages, genders, ethnicities, and other backgrounds. According to the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention, 48,344 people died by suicide in 2018. It is important to have honest discussions about this serious topic so people become aware of the signs and are comfortable speaking about it. Throughout the month of September, we will be sharing posts related to suicide, in hopes that it will foster conversation and awareness. If you have any concerns about your child’s mental health, please call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255.
For more resources on student supports regarding health and well-being please click here: https://sites.google.com/saugerties.k12.ny.us/resources/home

post_text: Even though the start of the school year is going to feature remote learning, some Saugerties teachers are already preparing their classrooms for their students’ return. At Mt. post_text: A hail storm that hammered the area two years ago left several sections of the Riccardi Elementary School roof damaged. The District temporarily fixed the issue but over time it began to leak. Starting several weeks ago, work crews began replacing the damaged roof. They replaced the rubber membrane over the gym (established in 1962) as well as added reinforcements and upgrades to the roof decking over the main part of the building (established 1938). Reinforcements were needed to meet State Education Department regulations for snow loads. The work is nearly complete and General Fund monies were appropriated in February 2019 for this project.

The New York State Public High School Athletic Association (NYSPHSAA) COVID-19 Task Force held their second meeting on Tuesday, June 30 to discuss potential scenarios in regards to interscholastic athletics when (or if) school reopens this fall. The scenarios are not set in stone but are designed to serve as a “starting point” to assist the Task Force in providing guidance and recommendations.
Representatives from the New York State Department of Health and the New York State Education Department (NYSED) provided updates pertaining to the COVID-19 crisis. The Task Force reviewed six potential proposals including a full return to athletic participation, season adjustments, the condensing of seasons and/or the creation of regional scenarios due to confirmed COVID-19 cases.
At this time, schools are still prohibited from any indoor activities, any in-person instruction, and any organized sports activities. We will keep you posted as we hear things.
If you have any questions concerning sports, please email the Athletic Director’s office at: dzarrella@saugerties.k12.ny.us

The day this joyous news arrived was June 19. We now come together each year on this date to celebrate freedom. This year, let us unite in the message that all people are created equal and shall be entitled to the rights of life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. #GoSawyers

The Saugerties Central School District will have two new principals when the 2020-2021 school year begins in September. On May 12, the Board of Education appointed Tim Reid as the principal of Saugerties High School and Ginger Vail as the principal of the Junior High School.

Reid currently serves as the vice principal of Miller Middle School in the Kingston City School District. He said he is humbled and excited about coming to Saugerties. “The High School has a great reputation and I am honored to have been chosen as its principal,” he said.

Vail has 24 years of experience in public education. Prior to being the assistant principal in Saugerties, she worked as a mathematics teacher and was the Mathematics Department Chairperson for the Junior/Senior High School. “The Saugerties community and its children matter greatly to me and always will,” she said. “I call them my own and in these virtual times, I miss them very much.”

Please give both of them a big Sawyer welcome and congratulations! #GoSawyers #SawyerStrong #SawyerProud

Reopening Schools: A Statewide, Virtual Conversation

New York State's 37 BOCES have launched an online conversation regarding how New Yorkers feel about returning to school in the fall or whenever it is possible. It consists of a single question: "What ideas and thoughts do you have as you think about a return to in-person schooling?"
A virtual conversation tool called Thoughtexchange is being used to crowdsource ideas. To participate in the exchange, visit: https://my.thoughtexchange.com/333518046.

After participants share a thought, they are encouraged to rate at least 30 of the thoughts submitted by other participants. This way, the thoughts that resonate with the most participants rise to the top.
“Understanding the thoughts and concerns of our stakeholders regarding reopening our school buildings is critical,” said Dr. Charles V. Khoury, district superintendent of Ulster BOCES. "The decisions before us are unprecedented, and we want to ensure our parents and community have a voice in this important conversation."

Students are identified in eighth grade and receive guidance counseling and mentoring through the completion of high school. Once students graduate, they are able to attend SUNY Ulster tuition-free for two years!

Students should complete an online application by May 31 which includes a short essay, and if selected by the school district, participate in a brief interview. Five candidates will be selected from each middle school.

For nearly 29 years, students at Mt. Marion and then later at Grant D. Morse Elementary School have published a school newspaper to highlight what’s been going on at the school.
The latest edition of Just Print It, which came out while schools were closed, has proved especially beneficial in keeping families updated and connected. Students were learning and reporting on the effects of the coronavirus on businesses, as well as well as sharing their personal feelings on our new “norm.” Grade 5 teacher and Just Print It publisher Joe Defino said, “This issue was significant because we take our role as recorders of history very seriously. The students do not know the full significance of what they do, but they will. Anyone who has been a part of this legacy takes ownership in its history and future.”
Defino says he is most proud of the fact that in 29 years, 158 regular editions, and 16 special editions, they missed only one deadline for publication and it wasn’t because of Covid-19. Practical learning at its best. #GDMMustangs #GoSawyers #AloneTogether

Attention 8th-graders! Will you be the first in your family to go to college? If so, apply for the President's Challenge Scholarship (PCS) at SUNY Ulster!

PCS assists first-generation college students with overcoming financial barriers associated with attending college. Students are identified in eighth grade and receive guidance counseling and mentoring through the completion of high school. Once students graduate, they are able to attend SUNY Ulster tuition-free for two years!

Students should complete an online application by May 31 which includes a short essay, and if selected by the school district, participate in a brief interview. Five candidates will be selected from each middle school.

If you’re looking for an activity to do with your kids, have them document their experience during the COVID-19 pandemic for a time capsule.

Our lives are marked by major news events — from landing on the moon, Hurricane Katrina, Pluto no longer being called a planet, to the events of 9/11 — and we often feel transported back in time when we recall them years later.

Now we find ourselves in another unprecedented time: a once-in-a-hundred-years pandemic that has the world in its grip. It will surely be referenced and studied by future generations.

One way to preserve our memories of this moment in time, is to make a time capsule. These time capsule sheets include letters from parents, a sheet to help explain how your feeling, and a place to document what you see the community doing. #GoSawyers #AloneTogether

post_text: Have you ever noticed how you breathe when you feel relaxed? It's different then when you are stressed. Deep breathing is one of the best ways to lower stress in the body. This is because when you breathe deeply, it sends a message to your brain to calm down and relax. The brain then sends this message to your body. Those things that happen when you are stressed, such as increased heart rate, fast breathing, and high blood pressure, all decrease as you breathe deeply to relax. post_text: The need to practice social distancing may have halted all physical field trips, but it hasn’t stopped Grade 2 students at Riccardi Elementary School from traveling around the country. Teacher Gina Pellegri took her students on a virtual 360-degree grand tour through several National Parks throughout the United States in honor of Earth Day 2020. Her class climbed glaciers at Kenai Fjords in Alaska; visited volcanic cliffs and explored lava tubes in Hawaii; walked through caverns at the Carlsbad Caverns National Park in New Mexico; and stargazed at Bryce Canyon National Park in Utah. Pellegri took her students on these tours through Google Arts & Culture’s “The Hidden Worlds of the National Parks” (https://artsandculture.withgoogle.com/en-us/). After the tour, students wrote down some of their thoughts in a reflection journal. She then asked them to explore their own backyards. During their next Google Meet, students will discuss some of the artifacts they found in their yards. #EarthDay #GoSawyers #AlongTogether #RiccardiRoars

This will not replace our emails and automated calls, however, SMS text messaging will allow for faster communications of announcements. We plan to use text messaging to send parents quick alerts on urgent school updates and events.

You will need to opt-in to receive SMS text messages from us. On Friday, April 10 you will receive a text message to the phone number you have on file. Follow the prompt if you want to continue receiving text messages.

Saugerties Central School District does not charge recipients for the text messages that they receive or send; however, wireless providers may charge for individual text messages, depending on the plan associated with the wireless device. Please consult your carrier if you are uncertain.

To receive these messages, we must have your cell phone number on file in Infinite Campus, our student information management system.

Important Info about Health Insurance:
With the recent closures of businesses across the State, many New Yorkers are at risk of losing their health insurance. Many are likely to be eligible for health coverage with financial assistance through NY State of Health (The Official Health Plan Marketplace) due to their loss of coverage and income.
New Yorkers who are without health insurance should apply now through NY State of Health. If you have lost employer coverage, you must apply within 60 days of losing that coverage. Because of a loss of income, New Yorkers may also be eligible for Medicaid, the Essential Plan, Child Health Plus, or subsidized Qualified Health Plan coverage.
Thousands of assistants are ready throughout the State to help consumers enroll by phone.
Visit www.nystateofhealth.ny.gov for assistance in helping to find a health care plan that works for you.
If you have additional questions, you can contact the Marketplace directly at 518-486-9102 or www.NYSOH@health.ny.gov.

The School District encourages everyone to respond to the Census as soon as you can. The information will help determine how many congressional seats and Electoral College votes each state gets, as well as the distribution of some $1.5 trillion in federal spending. You can reply by mail, on-line, or over the phone. To start a questionnaire now, please click here: https://my2020census.gov/

The U.S. Census Bureau has mailed out it’s 10-question survey to households across the country. The census is held every 10 years and uses the data collected in a variety of ways including: how many members of Congress a state will get to how federal funds will be spent. The Saugerties Central School District is encouraging all residents to participate in this national headcount, which directly benefits funding available to the school district and local community. For more information, visit bit.ly/2wsruc3. A Spanish version is available here: bit.ly/2Jhj0r0.

During the 2020 Census, the Census Bureau will never ask you for the following information: your Social Security number, money or donations, anything on behalf of a political party, your bank or credit card account numbers, or information regarding your citizenship.

post_text: This winter, Mt. Marion Grade 3 students have been learning about the science behind one of their favorite foods: maple syrup. Maple syrup enthusiast John Mullen has been traveling to the school in recent days, demonstrating how to tap some of the maple trees located on school grounds. The best time to tap, he explained, is when daytime temperatures are rising above the freezing point, and nighttime temperatures are falling below freezing. “That’s when the sap is flowing,” he said. The freezing-to-thawing cycle creates pressure within the closed system of the tree, he explained, causing the sap to flow. Students helped to drill holes into the trees and to set up the collection bags. Mullen also offered students a taste of syrup he’s processed the year before. Stay tuned for part two of this story later this evening. #MtMRams

Most teenagers post to some form of social media. Although social media can be used for many good things; it can also introduce risks teens should avoid.

It’s important to be aware of what your kids do on social media. But snooping can alienate them and damage the trust you both have built together. The key is to stay involved in a way that makes kids understand that you respect their privacy but what them to be safe.

One way to protect your kids is to follow the “What would Gramdma say?” rule. Teach kids not to share anything on social media that they wouldn’t want their teachers, college admissions officers, future bosses, and grandma to see.

Posting inappropriate photos of yourself or others can damage a reputation for years to come.

post_text: A marble rolls down a track and hits a set of dominos, which sets into motion a chain reaction. The dominos knock into a wooden block, which falls off the table, tugging a string. The tugging causes a can to swing into another set of systems, ultimately causing a candle to be blown out. All this, and more, was recently taking place in Technology teacher Bryan Van Vliet’s Grade 8 classroom as students worked to construct so-called Rube Goldberg devices. Named after cartoonist Rube Goldberg, the devices are machines that perform simple tasks in indirect, overly complicated ways. Speaking about his students’ work, Mr. Van Vliet said, “It may look like they are just playing games, but there is a lot of engineering, planning, organizing, and trial and error taking place.” #RubeGoldberg #GoSawyers

The Saugerties Central School District Board of Education recently updated and approved the District’s yearlong goals. The 2019/2020 goals focus on the following:
• Student achievement
• Culture, climate and community
• Safety and security

These goals have been established for each school in the District and building leadership has been notified of the updates.

Superintendent Kirk Reinhardt said, “The District’s goals will build on our students natural curiosity and learning styles, so that they will emerge as creative, collaborative, critical thinkers who can communicate effectively and persevere in a rapidly changing world in order to meet their individual potential.”

The goals also factored in overall student wellness and safety. “A student’s social, emotional, and physical well-being is just as important as their academic success,” Reinhardt said.

A monthly subscription costs $10.99, and can be cancelled at any time. There is also a yearly subscription available for $5.83 a month.
To subscribe to the NFHS Network, simply go to

To demonstrate their knowledge of plant and animal cells, students in Tina Mazzone’s Grade 7 Life Science class were asked to construct a 3D model of a cell of their choice. Students were encouraged to think outside of the box when it came to which medium they wanted to use. Students could use Play Doh, fabric, Styrofoam or even food. Each organelle also needed to be fully labeled with the name and function of the different parts of the cell.

Studying cells can help students understand how organisms, including humans, function. Did you know: Medical doctors have discovered that reducing body temperature can help a person survive a heart attack. Cold temperatures reduce the harm to heart and brain cells after a heart attack. By studying cells, doctors have been able to develop this new life-saving treatment. #GoSawyers
